node.html:
In a previous post I dived into the Danish Ministry of Educations school initiative to lift the students with the poorest academic performances. The point made in the post was that the evaluation of the schools relied on so little data, that the payouts would be a lottery. A couple of months ago the result and payout for each school was announced for the first year of the initiative. The ministry claims that 400 students improved their performance as a result of the initiative 1.

The 62 schools have on average decreased the proportion of students on that level with almost 14 percentage points compared to their starting points. This amounts to the schools improving more than 400 students.

The Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR) had gained access to documents detailing the performance for this year and the three previous years, where amongst other things found schools that received the payout but had decreased the general performance 2. I asked them to share their data to have a closer look. It turned out that not only had the ministry not accounted for regression towards the mean, they also only included schools who actually improved not all schools in the initiative and they used a regular mean where a weighted mean should have been applied. With these errors the true number of students improved as a result of the initiative is closer to 200 than 400.

I shared this finding with DR where it was used as part of a larger section on the initiative in their fact-checking programme “Detektor” the 18th of October 3.

To come up with the figure 400, the ministry only included the schools who got a payout from the initiative. They then computed the average improvement for these schools and multiplied it onto the total number of students graduating from these schools. By this method they arrived at 405. There are three problems with this method:

  1. To begin with you can not take an un-weighted average improvement over all the schools and then apply it to the total number of students. It turns out that the small schools have improved more than the larger schools (which is to be expected as small schools will regress more towards the mean). Taking the weighted average instead brings the number down to 355 students.
  2. Only including the improved schools when accounting for the number of improved students is a very blunt form of cherry-picking. Including all schools that have participated in the initiative brings the number down to 287. Where the first mistake is embarrassing I will categorize this one as deceitful.
  3. Finally, as mentioned in the previous post, one must take care to account for regression toward the mean. The schools in the initiative were selected for poor performance. Being on such a list is a product of true effects such as socioeconomic factors and bad luck. Where the true effects remain from year to year, luck changes from year to year. Accounting for regression to the mean the number is down to 221 students. This number is subject to some uncertainty, as we need to estimate the effect of regression towards the mean. This mistake is more forgiveable but a mistake nonetheless.

A data sheet with the schools, their baseline performance, number of students, performance this year etc. can be found here.
